dashboard.subtitle: Analyse de tendance de la mortalite et morbidite

sections.title: Objectifs
sections.content:
Les objectifs sp√©cifiques sont :

‚Ä¢ Strat√©gies de pr√©vention : √âvaluer l'√©volution temporelle des campagnes de distribution de masse de moustiquaires impr√©gn√©es d'insecticide longue dur√©e (MILD), la distribution de routine par les cliniques pr√©natales (CPN) et les plateformes de vaccination (PEV), ainsi que la Distribution en Milieu Scolaire (DMS). Analyser la couverture et l'impact de la Pulv√©risation Intradomiciliaire d'Insecticide (PID) l√† o√π elle est mise en ≈ìuvre ;

‚Ä¢ Prise en charge des cas et diagnostic : Comparer les tendances de disponibilit√© et d'utilisation des tests de diagnostic rapide (TDR) et de la microscopie dans les formations sanitaires, l'acc√®s en temps opportun aux m√©dicaments antipaludiques de qualit√© assur√©e, et la formation/supervision des agents de sant√© sur les directives de traitement ;

‚Ä¢ Surveillance, suivi et √©valuation : Comparer les tendances des diff√©rents syst√®mes de collecte de donn√©es, de rapportage et d'utilisation du DHIS2 ; analyser l'√©volution des taux de positivit√© des tests, de l'incidence et des tendances de mortalit√© ; √©valuer la surveillance communautaire ;

‚Ä¢ Engagement communautaire et changement social de comportement : Identifier les indicateurs d'efficacit√© des strat√©gies CSCC qui pr√©sentent des tendances similaires √† celles des indicateurs de couverture, et ceux qui diff√®rent, afin de mieux comprendre l'appropriation communautaire et le r√¥le de la DMS dans l'autonomisation des enfants scolaris√©s comme champions de la pr√©vention du paludisme ;

‚Ä¢ Gouvernance du programme et coordination : Analyser l'√©volution des capacit√©s institutionnelles, des partenariats entre le MdS et le MBSSE, et des m√©canismes de financement des interventions antipaludiques dans les diff√©rentes r√©gions.

sections.title: Impact Indicators Overview
sections.content: Analysis of key malaria impact indicators including case incidence, test positivity rates, mortality rates, and hospital admissions across Sierra Leone.

sections.title: Mortality and Test Positivity Analysis
sections.content: Comprehensive review of malaria mortality patterns and diagnostic testing outcomes.

sections.title: Case Reporting Analysis
sections.content: Analysis of inpatient deaths and reported malaria cases (both presumed and confirmed) trends.

sections.content: National overview of malaria crude incidence trends and district-level subplot analysis.

sections.content: Chiefdom-level crude incidence mapping for Eastern Province districts.

sections.content: Crude incidence trends in Kambia, Karene, and Port Loko districts.

sections.title: üå¥ Southern Province Districts
sections.content: Southern Province malaria trends including Bo, Bonthe, Moyamba, and Pujehun.

sections.content: Urban and rural Western Area crude incidence analysis.

sections.content: CHIE (Chiefdom Health Information Exchange) subplot analysis across key districts.

sections.content: Analysis of suspected malaria cases reporting patterns and trends across all districts.

sections.title: üìà Suspected Cases Trends
sections.content: Temporal analysis of suspected malaria case reporting by district and region.

sections.title: üß™ Testing Overview
sections.content: Analysis of malaria testing coverage, methods used (RDT vs microscopy), and testing trends.

sections.title: ‚öïÔ∏è Testing Capacity Analysis

sections.content: Analysis of confirmed malaria cases, confirmation rates, and diagnostic accuracy patterns.

sections.title: üìä Confirmation Rate Trends
sections.content: Temporal and spatial analysis of malaria case confirmation rates and patterns.

sections.content: Analysis of malaria treatment coverage, drug availability, and treatment completion rates.

sections.title: üéØ Treatment Outcomes
sections.content: Assessment of treatment effectiveness and patient outcomes across different regions.

sections.title: üè† Indoor Residual Spraying
sections.content: Assessment of IRS implementation, coverage, and effectiveness in targeted areas.

sections.title: üè´ School-Based Distribution Program
sections.content: Evaluation of the School-Based Distribution program implementation and outcomes.

sections.content: Assessment of data quality, completeness, and utilization from the DHIS2 system.

sections.title: üìã Reporting Quality Assessment
sections.content: Analysis of data reporting timeliness, completeness, and accuracy across facilities.

sections.title: üîç Key Findings
sections.content:
The Malaria Program Review reveals significant progress in several areas while highlighting critical gaps that require immediate attention:

‚Ä¢ Decline in Incidence: Overall reduction in malaria incidence across most districts
‚Ä¢ Improved Testing: Increased diagnostic testing coverage and quality
‚Ä¢ Enhanced Surveillance: Strengthened data collection and reporting systems
‚Ä¢ Prevention Success: School-Based Distribution showing promising results

sections.title: ‚ö†Ô∏è Key Challenges Identified
sections.content:
‚Ä¢ Geographic Disparities: Persistent high transmission areas in certain districts
‚Ä¢ Resource Constraints: Limited funding affecting intervention scale-up
‚Ä¢ Health System Gaps: Inadequate staffing and infrastructure in remote areas
‚Ä¢ Data Quality Issues: Inconsistent reporting from some facilities
‚Ä¢ Community Engagement: Variable levels of community participation

sections.title: üìù Strategic Recommendations
sections.content:
‚Ä¢ Scale-up SBD: Expand School-Based Distribution to all districts
‚Ä¢ Strengthen Surveillance: Improve data quality and real-time monitoring
‚Ä¢ Target High-Risk Areas: Focus resources on persistent transmission hotspots
‚Ä¢ Enhance Partnerships: Strengthen coordination between health and education sectors
‚Ä¢ Community Mobilization: Increase community ownership and participation
‚Ä¢ Capacity Building: Train additional health workers and improve supervision

sections.title: üöÄ Next Steps (2025-2030)
sections.content:
‚Ä¢ Strategic Plan Development: Develop new 5-year malaria strategic plan
‚Ä¢ Resource Mobilization: Secure funding from Global Fund and other partners
‚Ä¢ Implementation Framework: Establish clear timelines and accountability mechanisms
‚Ä¢ Monitoring System: Implement robust M&E framework with regular reviews
‚Ä¢ Innovation Integration: Pilot new technologies and approaches

sections.title: üôè Special Thanks
sections.content: We extend our sincere gratitude to all partners, stakeholders, and communities who made this Malaria Program Review and School-Based Distribution initiative a tremendous success.

sections.title: ü§ù Key Partners and Collaborators
sections.content:
‚Ä¢ Ministry of Health and Sanitation (MoHS) - Strategic leadership and policy guidance
‚Ä¢ National Malaria Control Programme (NMCP) - Technical expertise and program coordination
‚Ä¢ President's Malaria Initiative (PMI) - Financial support and technical assistance
‚Ä¢ Abt Associates - Implementation support and capacity building
‚Ä¢ School Administrators and Teachers - Frontline implementation and student engagement
‚Ä¢ School Quality Assurance (SQA) Officers - Quality monitoring and supervision
‚Ä¢ PHU Staff - Community-level health service delivery
‚Ä¢ Community Leaders - Mobilization and advocacy support
‚Ä¢ Students and Families - Active participation and program champions

sections.title: üè¢ Institutional Support
sections.content:
‚Ä¢ WHO Sierra Leone - Technical guidance and standards
‚Ä¢ UNICEF - Child health and education sector coordination
‚Ä¢ Global Fund - Financial resources and program oversight
‚Ä¢ Ministry of Basic and Senior Secondary Education (MBSSE) - Educational platform access
‚Ä¢ District Health Management Teams - Local coordination and supervision
‚Ä¢ Chiefdom Health Committees - Community-level governance and support
